Members of the human network need to be able to communicate from anywhere, at any time.
Locating each other and establishing reliable communications channels between us requires a system of global addresses that is both flexible and dynamic.
In this chapter, you will learn the basics of the IP addressing structure that enables users all over the world to communicate across the network.
After completion of this chapter, you should be able to:
Describe the purpose of an IP address and subnet mask, and how they are used on the Internet.
Describe the types of IP addresses available.
Describe the methods of obtaining an IP address.
Describe the use of NAT on a home or small business network using an ISR.
